Student-critic contest winners

Kahlil Vineyard of Fern Creek High School reviews touring music, wins competition

Student-critic contest winners

Shelby Nasser won for her video review of 'Newsies.'

Louisville 1:38 p.m. EST December 3, 2014

Dan DeLuca, center, as Jack Kelly, with cast of “Newsies.”(Photo: Deen Van Meer)

4 CONNECT 11 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

When the Tony Award-winning musical "Newsies" started a run at the Kentucky Center on Nov. 18, The Courier-Journal hosted high school journalism students from throughout the region who had signed up to review the opening night performance along with CJ critic Elizabeth Kramer.

More than a week before that event, the students had met with Kramer to talk about American musical theater, the role of a critic and elements of theater criticism. Courier-Journal photographer and videographer Scott Utterback was was there to talk about making videos for students wanting to try their hand behind the camera.

The students' submitted reviews were read by a jury that included Kramer, Utterback, arts and features editor Jana John and Cathy Colliver, brand manager at Courier-Journal Media. Here are the winner and two runners-up selected by the panel.

Winner

'Newsies' seizes the day at the Kentucky Center

By Kahlil Vineyard

Fern Creek High School

If you're looking for pure, unlimited fun in the form of an energetic, brilliantly choreographed musical, a seat at "Newsies" is a perfect fit. The vigorous show that just can't seem to sit still arrived at the Kentucky Center for the Arts on November 18, dazzling audiences with a performance that refused to rest. Ask a "Newsies" audience member what they experienced, and you'll probably get a response along the lines of "ruthless entertainment."

“Don't be fooled by the historical context; this show is anything but a boring recount of past events. ”

Kahil Vineyard, Fern Creek High School

Set in the late 1890s following the Spanish-American War, which fueled newspaper sales with sensationalism, "Newsies" follows ambitious male lead Jack Kelly. Kelly is looking for more than the underprivileged life of a New York paper boy. Kelly and the other boys struggle to sell enough papers for The World, owned by the wealthy Joseph Pulitzer, due to a lack of juicy headlines. The boys are put at an even greater disadvantage when the wealthy Pulitzer decides to raise the price of papers in order to force higher sales by newsboys in a time of drab stories. Outraged at the 10 cent increase from 50 to 60, the boys begin to talk of rebelling against the wealthy paper owner to ensure they have enough to get by. And so begins the revolutionary Newsboys' Strike of 1899 that represented one of the first labor strikes coordinated by children in U.S. History.

Don't be fooled by the historical context; this show is anything but a boring recount of past events. The production avoids a drab, overdone storytelling method, and conveys the majority of the plot through loud beats and mesmerizing dance moves. The aggressive stomping and quick moving choreography of "Seize the Day" captures the bottled up anger that the paper boys are now directing at the elites of the paper industry. The surrounding soundtrack boasts a marching army-like beat, as the newsboys declare they're fed up and won't take it any longer.

Alan Menken, who has worked on numerous past Disney successes like "The Little Mermaid" and "Beauty and the Beast," and Jack Feldman team up to develop the aggressive, rebellious score that elegantly complements the vigorous dance moves. The two have managed to turn a history lesson into a pleasure filled spectacle that is nothing short of sweet eye candy.

Although there are plenty of foot tapping songs and dance numbers that are raw entertainment, "Newsies" also features decent character development. Menken and Feldman use their song writing abilities to craft powerful, heartfelt moments devoid of dancing that allow the audience to connect with characters. Viewers get to know the lead character of Kelly with the forceful solo number entitled "Santa Fe" that outlines inner conflict. Kelly blames himself for putting his fellow newsboys in danger by leading the strike, forcing him to contemplate the daring action of giving up and moving out west. The weight of Kelly's decision is effectively conveyed to the audience as he belts the eruptive climax with raw emotion. There are no catchy beats or flashy dance scenes, just Kelly and the audience.

"Newsies" doesn't set any high standards or make any breakthroughs in the theatre realm, but does something much simpler: produces well-crafted fun. The production finds a comfortable balance between a good story, characters, etc. and the entertaining eye candy that is characteristic of most musicals. You may not be blown away or emotionally changed by Newsies, but you'll smile, tap your foot, and want to come back for more.

Second Place

The World Will Know

By Anna Jean Soto

Christian Academy of Louisville

A strike only occurs amidst assertiveness and courage, traits usually not developed in children. This makes it significant that in 1899 the newsboys of New York organized a strike. They had a dilemma because the Spanish American war recently ended, so the newspapers weren't selling. Newsboys had to buy the papers from the printers with their own money. The newsboys had a strike because the publishers charged the inflated price for their "papes" after the war, leaving the poor boys unable to make any money. It was violent and hard to endure, but it turned out to be the first successful strike ever organized by children. The big business owners Joseph Pulitzer and William Randolph Hearst agreed to buy back any papers the Newsies did not sell, which was a significant improvement. This inspiring story morphed into a Disney Broadway musical with a screenplay written by Tony Award winning book writer Harvey Fierstein. The Newsies successfully conquer the evil business men after a hard fought battle, but they easily conquer the hearts of the audience.

“The exciting and purposeful singing is enhanced greatly by the sound system in the theater. ”

Anna Jean Soto, Christian Academy Louisville

The main character, Jack Kelly, played by Dan DeLuca, is a true triple threat on Broadway. He can act, sing, and dance with gusto. The audience can feel his concern for the other newsboys and his rage at being exploited. His voice is strong, and his dancing leads the newsies through almost every entertaining number. The villain, Pulitzer, played by Steve Blanchard, has a good feel for his role, and the audience immediately knows he's a real jerk. His goal is obviously to make money by taking advantage of children, the epitome of evil almost begging to be conquered. The female lead is the reporter, Katherine Plumber, played by Stephanie Styles, who has a melodious voice and comic talent. She and Jack, however, do not have real chemistry in most of the play. She seems abrupt and abrasive in the beginning, but gradually warms into her role. The other main female character is Medda Larkin, played by Angela Grovey, and she fits seamlessly into her role. This salon owner has a genuine and frequently humorous personality and a booming, beautiful voice.

These characters flourish in the interactive sets. The sets are tremendous at transporting the audience into the moment. They look very rough, like the streets of New York. They are also an engineering wonder considering the giant metal pillars move and interlock like puzzle pieces during the production. It's quite terrifying. The boys jump on and between metal towers while they move and spin. It seems inevitable that one will fall and be crushed, but they all keep flowing through the scenery, adding to the feeling of reckless danger that would naturally follow orphaned boys on the streets of New York. Accompanying the moving sets are retractable screens that give interesting insight into small details of the play. When Jack Kelly is drawing something, the drawing appears on the screen, synched to his hand movement. A picture also appears the exact moment it is taken, making the audience feel like they are in the production. The exciting and purposeful singing is enhanced greatly by the sound system in the theater. The mike volume is right on key. The loud scenes do not hurt one's ears, and the audience never has to strain to hear the softer scenes.

“Now on to the most thrilling component of the production: the dancing! ”

Anna Jean Soto

Now on to the most thrilling component of the production: the dancing! These dancers are some of the best in New York. Watching them is fascinating. Vigorous movement is combined with precision and timing in everything they do, from gymnastics to tap dancing to throwing dancers over each other's heads. Newspaper is also cleverly worked into some dances. The boys dance on top of it, and it becomes a type of spinning board, allowing them even more impressive turn times.

The last thing that really makes "Newsies" a gem is its emotional impact. Laughs are threaded throughout the whole production and yet there are some truly poignant scenes. The production feels like Annie, except with all boys. The boys handle their hard knock life with spunk, but it is more thrilling than "Annie," because of the wildness and humor a male cast generates. They radiate energy and excitement, and their athleticism is overwhelming. A feeling of triumph and empowerment pervades the room whenever the boys have a little success at fighting back. It shows the boys know they are not worthless and that they have power when banded together. Don't miss this sensational, heartfelt production!

Third Place

Disney's Newsies strikes up talk in Louisville

By Delaney Smith

Floyd Central High School

Extra! Extra! Read all about it! Disney's "Newsies" takes over the Kentucky Center for the Arts from November 18-23. Jake Kelly (Dan DeLuca) and his band of New York newsboys transport their patrons back to a time long overlooked by many, the Newsboys Strike of 1899. This is when the newsboys (newsies) rose up against the tyrant Joseph Pulitzer (Steve Blanchard), the editor and owner of New York's The World newspaper. By Pulitzer raising the price of papers for the newsies, it forces the boys to have to sell more just to make the same miniscule pay that they are already forced to live on. These young boys are starving and stealing just to survive on the streets of New York City, so this raise in price is the final straw for the newsies.

Director Jeff Calhoun makes the lives of these poor young boys come to life for the modern day viewer. The first scene really gives a great insight to the homeless life of NYC in the 1890's. The boys, Jack and Crutchie (Zachary Sayle), represent two different sides to the same coin. Jack is a dreamer, full of hope and promise for a future that is bright and far, far away from the big city. He dreams of a simple life in a small town where life is easy. Santa Fe is the final destination for him and his dreams. On the other hand Crutchie is more of a realist, though eventually he is persuaded into thinking more about Santa Fe as Jack continues to describe it to him.

“One minor criticism is that although this musical is a Disney production, this is not the most child-friendly show.”

Delany Smith, Floyd Central High School

One minor criticism is that although this musical is a Disney production, this is not the most child-friendly show. Going into anything with the Disney name on it, many expect a show that used child-friendly language and clean humor. This show however did not fit this description. The very first song of the show had cursing in it. Right off the bat there were signs of more to come. Throughout the show there was a bit more cursing, but nothing extreme. The parts that seemed to catch most off guard though, were some of the jokes. The mention of "skirt-chasers" and other sexual references made for some raunchy jokes along the way. Although these jokes were very amusing for the adult audience, they were not necessarily suitable for younger spectators.

The choreography in this show was a spectacle all its own. The way that Christopher Gattelli used extremely well-executed routines to help make the story come to life, while also keeping the boys looking tough like we would expect boys on the streets to be, is an absolute stroke of genius. Somehow, Gattelli manages to make even aspects of ballet look rough and tough throughout the performance. The actors kept in perfect time with one another and made the dances really something memorable.

Disney's "Newsies" comes with a strong message to adults and kids alike. No matter how small someone may seem, they can still change the world. This is a true David-verses-Goliath story and still is very much in play today. The lesson taught withstands the test of time. These kids stood up for what they believed in and it paid off. This shows that anything worth getting, is worth fighting for and that just because things get tough, never give up. This show was a total success and is well on its way to becoming a Broadway classic. The brilliant music, choreography, sets and acting make it a production to remember.

Insights into "Newsies" from other participating students

Amber Bartley, Floyd Central High School

Sets change with such an exceptional speed and are completely pleasing. Colossal 24-foot-tall towers of metal boxes connect to look like fire escape stairs. On the front of the boxes are transparent screens. Throughout the performance, various visuals will appear on the screen, such as when Jack writes "STRIKE" across the incoming news board. The technology to be able to pull that off is just a highly neat idea that should expand into other productions.

Likewise, the lighting has an astounding and dynamic effect on the authenticity of the musical. Subtle oranges and yellows during the quieter moments, and a vibrant blue during louder moments. However, some scenes seemed to have too much white light. The pure scenes of just one or two characters and a spotlight worked well.

Sydney Blocker, duPont Manual High School

Indeed, the choreography and the characters of "Newsies" made the piece worthy of being above the fold, but the music was the propelling force. The sometimes humorous, sometimes serious lyrics combined with the powerful score created an experience the audience could not look away from. The music told the story of the characters when words couldn't do justice. From the somber compositions that narrated Jack Kelly's longing for Santa Fe to the vociferous introduction of Miss Medda and even the anxious frustration Katherine Plumber experienced when trying to type up her breakout article as a hard news reporter, the musical score was carefully crafted and enhanced the character's story incredibly. Furthermore, the musical masterpieces were flat out contagious. Upon the final bows and curtsies of the cast, patrons left their seats humming "Newsies" standout number, "Seize the Day."

Olivia Marie Evans, duPont Manual High School

The entire cast did a good job speaking and acting from the heart. Another interesting facet of this musical was the set. The stage was transformed from nothing to a part of New York in a flash. On the stage there where metal skywalks that connected to each other but could also be separated and moved for other scenes. On these skywalks there was a screen which video rolls and illustrations would appear so the audience could see what the news boys where looking at in the distance or what they were reading and writing as well.

Zachary Gabbert, Oldham County High School

The world generated was full of vibrant characters that all relished in their impressive vocal range. Katherine is introduced as a hard, no-nonsense type, which I was not loving at first. I'll go as far as to say that I was hoping she would soon be discarded by the ladies-man protagonist. By "Watch What Happens,: a song in the first half of the show, I was pleasantly surprised to find her character shifting into this crusader that wasn't afraid to call out Kelly on his cowardice and stand up for what she knows is right, regardless of what it did to her reputation. Strong and true, Styles' voice makes Katherine come to life.

Cara Hall, Christian Academy of Louisville

The world generated was full of vibrant characters that all relished in their impressive vocal range. Catherine is introduced as a hard, no-nonsense type, which I was not loving at first. I'll go as far as to say that I was hoping she would soon be discarded by the ladies-man protagonist. By Watch What Happens, a song in the first half of the show, I was pleasantly surprised to find her character shifting into this crusader that wasn't afraid to call out Kelly on his cowardice and stand up for what she knows is right, regardless of what it did to her reputation. Strong and true, Styles' voice makes Catherine come to life.

Sarah Haney, Walden School

One cannot help but to gape in awe at the physical exertion put forth by the newsies in fast-paced, on edge, stimulating choreography by Tony Award winning Christopher Gattelli, involving countless backflips, spins, and splits (yes!). The choreography possibly might even match their dynamic commitment for justice after papers, run by the infamous Pulitzer and Hearst, are upped in price for the newsies who already struggle to feed themselves.

Haley Kaelin, duPont Manual High School

Many underlying themes were at play during the musical, each for one's own interpretation. "Newsies" was all about freedom, looking for something more and standing up for what you believe in, but also had a lot to say about child labor. Based on a true story, the newsies' strike inspired strikes nationwide in the early 20th century. The truth behind the musical played a major factor in contributing to the passion the story delivered to the audience.

Rachel Lamb, Floyd Central High School

Little did I know, there is a twist in between the constant singing in every scene and dance routines, performed by the talented newsies that has everyone intrigued throughout the entire play, including me.

As the strike is unfolding, Jack falls in love with a young, outgoing newspaper reporter, Katherine. Their chemistry is noticeable from the very beginning of the production, which is why I think the audience and I especially paid close attention to the two characters.

Many secrets are revealed when her idea to secretly print off a story about the strike, in order to help out the boys, lands Jack in trouble with The World publisher Joseph Pulitzer.

Nic Moore, Oldham County High School

I found that "Newsies" thrives when using their technology to its full potential. With Jack Kelly (played by Dan DeLuca), the leader of the newsboys, drawings being projected onto the screen in real time, or when the lead story is being "written" across the virtual chalkboard. It's in moments like these, which makes the show feel more like an experience.

I'm glad to say that a younger audience isn't the sole demographic "Newsies" will appeal to. Generally, this is common criticism that tends to arise when it comes to Disney. But with jokes scattered throughout that may go over the heads of a younger audience, it manages to leave something for an older crowd to enjoy on their own.

Kaleb Mount, Scottsburg High School

As the show progresses and Katherine develops a special relationship with Jack, the story takes a turn for the worse. Katherine's personality just simply can't stand next to the behemoth of Jack's. The love story seems thrown in as a formality and not as an actual boon to the plot of the show. During the sappy interactions between Kelly and Plumber, I found myself wanting to see more of the tense interactions between Kelly and Pulitzer. The two are barely ever in the same room, but when they are the chemistry is fantastic.

In my opinion, the whole story needed more of the strike and less of the love. If only the writers had been on that same train of thought, I would have left the theater even happier than I was. It felt to me like they threw in the romance to attract date-night theater goers. This is a point where the ambition of the show becomes a problem. Neither the love nor the strike is really completely focused on in the second act, and this causes people who long for one and people who long for the other to be left disappointed.

Madeline Wainwright, duPont Manual High School

Some stand outs are the littlest newsie boy Les (played by Vincent Crocilla), whose adorable lines yet strong delivery almost steal some of the scenes — then there is the set! If you did not know when and where the story took place, then the set and costumes would tell you. The sets dark gray and sleek scaffolding was always moving and with the picturesque scenes represented their struggle and made you feel you were in the desperate times. The period costumes with the worn, weathered look were all topped with the classic paperboy hat all really fit the characters. The boxy scaffolding was an important part of framing each boy while making the scene stand out.

Jack Webb, Christian Academy of Louisville

The musical astonishingly blends comedy, romance, and tragedy into one perfectly crafted piece of art. It correctly displays how a musical should operate, with its fast-paced, easy-to-follow story and lovable, energetic characters. Incredibly talented actors Dan DeLuca (Jack Kelly) and Stephanie Styles (Katherine Plumber) have phenomenal chemistry and their onstage love seems real every night. Straight from the beginning, DeLuca and Styles' characters felt very relatable and inspiring to the audience, and the newsies' conflict reminds teenagers and adults alike that hard work and passion for what you love pays off.

ZoraAnn Woodsmall, Paoli Junior/Senior High School

Then there is Katherine Plumber (Stephanie Styles), who plays a key role in this revolt. She is a female journalist, attempting to make a name for herself in the journalism industry at a time when women were mostly confined to the social pages. She becomes part of this strike by writing about it in the newspaper despite her actions getting her blacklisted as a journalist. This spreads the word, getting more people aware and passionate about what is happening. Her character sends a message about how women were perceived at this time and proved the success that can be made.

Morgan Woodrum,Butler Traditional High School

The scenery was the most remarkable aspect of "Newsies." When attending a musical set during the Industrial Revolution time period, it is normal to have anticipations of a plain backdrop in a rustic atmosphere. However, the scenic designer (Tobin Ost) and the lighting designer (Jeff Croiter) went above and beyond to create an atmosphere that painted the vivid image of the Industrial Revolution perfectly. The two designers proved that modern day technology aids in creating some of the most astonishing scenes ever produced.

COURIER-JOURNAL
